reviewText:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bo-XbNxd7uU

This game has a cool core idea but also feels like some kind of twisted marketing experiment by Disney to see what players would let them get away with. It's shallow, it's buggy and it's full of microtransaction scumminess that would barely be acceptable in a free-to-play game but is in full force in one that costs a minimum of $20.

The basic idea is cool. It's a score attack runner game that has two modes, one on foot and one in light cycles. Each mode has their own levels, mechanics and challenges and despite a lacking sense of speed, everything feels fluid, responsive and it's actually quite fun. Though there are only 16 levels for each mode, plus a randomly generated endless mode where you race for time instead of score, you're encouraged to replay levels for better scores and there can be a decent number of hours involved in completing everything if that's your thing.

Where this completely breaks down is with the powerups and the microtransactions tied to them. Yes, this is a minimum $20 game that has microtransactions. Now, they're very much optional and grinding out in-game currency to buy powerups actually doesn't take that long. That said, the powerups are single use so you might have to grind a lot. Where this falls apart is YOU CAN BUY POWER! There are powerups that will both double your combo accumulation AND double your score! You can literally buy higher scores on the leaderboards. This completely renders the core competitive loop of this game worthless as it's not a level playing field and those willing to grind or spend money do better by default. For that reason alone, you shouldn't buy this game. This is a business model that deserves to fail.

The game looks very good and nails the TRON aesthetic but the PC version is a mess. You can only quit the game by pressing ESC on the title screen, something not documented anywhere. You can't rebind any of the controls. There are UI glitches, especially in the Stream endless mode. Load times are long, even on high-end machines and as of writing, the leaderboards which you can buy your way up on don't even work! Every time I try to bring them up, it sits at Loading and never shows anything.

There's a great TRON-inspired idea here but the game is buggy, overpriced for what you get and the microtransaction strategy ruins it. I'd expect this in a free-to-play mobile game, not a $20 PC release. Such potential wasted. DON'T BUY THIS!

After two hours of play, I didn't manage to complete a single mission, and I'm hardly the worst gamer ever. I knew this wasn't going to be Tron 2.0, but I didn't expect the light-cycle equilivant of bullet hell. Coming out when this did, one assumes the makers were hoping that more Tron content would help revitalize interest in the franchise, but all it really does is represent a final nail in the coffin.

reviewText:
Previously recommended during the early access period. This game had a ton of potential during the 2-3 months of early access. The developer picked up on some of the community requested features and tried their best to implement as much as they possibly could. Unfortunately, I now see that a lot of those community ideas were instead used to generate cash grab opportunities for Disney. I won't hold this against Sanzaru Games as they have done an incredible job nailing the look and feel of this universe. Everything else is politics on Disney's end.

Positive Impressions
-Gameplay is solid. No input delay. Run, jump, glide, slide, wall run, attack, Tony Hawk 360 skatepark and light cycle your way to the finish. Supports keyboard + mouse and controller.
-Visually a very beautiful game and manages to capture the neon-glow vibrance of the TRON universe. Colour palette is buffed slightly from TRON: Evolution.
-Soundtrack is solid and adds a level of depth and dramatic feel to the whole experience.
-Steam achievements for the 100% go-getter.

Negative Impressions
-No tangible story or anything of substance to back some sort of continuity for the player. I realise this may not be a necessary feature for most runner games, but the desire to progress slowly deteriorates as repetiveness takes over soon after the first few missions (with the exception of boss encounters). The currently available 32 levels becomes a chore rather than an exhilerating journey with a justifiable cause to progress.
-Leaderboard is forever loading. This game is far from a 'finished' product.
-I previously reported randomly losing health and hero suddenly turning invisible during the running segments whilst under early access. I continue to experience these bugs.
-Performance issues continue to persist since day one of early access despite numerous reviewers and members of the community being vocal about stability issues. Some bugs (like those mentioned above) and frame rate issues continue to persist.
-Light cycle segments are an absolute drag. The developers should have focused solely on the running segments with newer and more intuitive features. The light cycle portions just don't feel right at all.
-Main menu? What main menu. There is no such thing here! No options menu unless you hit escape, and no way to exit the game unless you return to the very top menu and hit escape.
-The base game will set you back by £14.99 and an optional £19.00 for the ultimate upgrade. That totals to £33.99. Slightly overzealous, don't you think Disney? I purchased this during early access and splashed £6.99. THAT should be the price for the current content available in the base game alone. Everything else is a perfect opportunity for Disney to slag off the TRON and Steam community. Your money is best invested elsewhere.

Had I known this would be the embarrasing route Disney originally intented I would have avoided RUN/r right from the beginning. Yes, I am in love with the TRON universe and yes I did purchase this with little knowledge. However, I had no regrets at the time even with the bare bones content. I wanted to support this project and was satisfied with the content I saw and the expectations bouncing between the community. From here onwards I will be extremely vigilant towards all future entries in this universe, especially anything baring the Disney label.

First of all, this game is an absolute BEAUTY to behold! The environments are fantastic and really makes you feel like you are a program trying to get to the portal and escape from the Grid. Also, the effects and lighting that's used is perfect and it makes the Grid come alive!

The object of the game is to get to the portal. In the disc mode, this means running along, jumping and sliding, dodging attacks, throwing your disc, wall running, gliding, and even grinding on rails to get to the end in one piece. You have 3 energy (health points). If you lose all your energy, you lose. The controls handle great for this mode and it's easy to get into and learn but tricky to master especially when you're running quickly and trying to deal with everything in front of you.

The second mode is the light cycle mode and it's also a lot of fun, but very challenging. The reason it's so challenging and brutal is that you have to get to the end before the time runs out, but the catch is that you have to go through check point gates to keep the time up. The gates will have different second amounts they will add such as 2, 4, and 6 seconds. If you run out of time, you lose. This mode is tough, and it really is a try, try, and try again until beat it sort of mode.

The third mode is STREAM" which is basically an endless randomly generated run which can switch between disc and cycle modes to keep you on your toes. It is a lot of fun and is great to come to and play if you need a break from the other two modes because instead of being pre-made like the others

Endless runner players, you'll most likely enjoy this game.

As of this review, TRON RUN/r has six runner Disk levels and six Light Cycle levels. All of them are quite enjoyable and worth a go. Optimization and responsiveness seem good, no issues whatsoever on my system. Only a few minor grpahical quirks have been seen, some of which were recently corrected in the latest patch. What this game needs IMNSHO is a DIsk battle arena (Disk Wars) such as we saw in Legacy. Some game mode with a greater control over our character could not hurt either.

While the design and layout of the hand-created levels is quite nice, over time they may become stale. I would like to see the building blocks of these levels used for some kind of procedural level generation, or an endless runner mode (or both).

The core of this game is there, and quite promising. As of yet we have no idea how much more will be added, but more of the same is certainly not unreasable to expect. The low cost of entry makes this easy to recommend based on the current state and the forthcoming potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

3 things I love about Tron: Cyberpunk; neon lit cities; orchestral electro with that 8-bit feeling. And Tron has all of that in one! ^-^

At the moment, this game has only 3 levels, but each one is very fun to play. I found it quite challenging sometimes actually when I try and get the highest score on each of the levels (which is a good thing, I like having a challenge)! At first I thought this game was an 'endless runner' but knowing that there is a finish to each level is towards my preference. I suppose it would be nice to add in an endless mode for those who want that. The game features currency called BITS you collect on the run and you can spend these on upgrades which will help you achieve a higher score.

Pros:
-Fluid controls, no delay when quickly dodging away from a close obstacle.
-The grind isn't real, so this is friendly to those who don't have enough time to play.
-Beautiful looking game. May not compete against BF5 but it still looks nice with everything glowing.
-Major satisfaction when dancing around the place throwing your disc at spiders.
-It's Tron.

Cons:
-Settings are a tad limited. No key mapping, no graphics setting etc.
Bugs. I know it's an early access there will be bugs - however there aren't many bugs and the ones in the game don't put you off but I'll note them here for the developers to see.
-Framerate issue on Discmap02. At some parts of the beginning it began to drop at quite a low level.
-Wall run issue. Sometimes when I glide towards a wall and start to run against it I phase through like quick sand... But I pop out again before I have to switch paths so not all hope was lost.


Overall this game is really good, if you want to buy it maybe wait until there is more content unless you want that Tron goodness in your veins early. I would also add suggestions to this review but I figured whatever I have in mind the developers have already begun making.

Also, here's Discmap01 to give you a taste of what the game is like:

I'd no idea a new Tron game was in the works so seeing TRON RUN/r was a pleasant surprise.

The game in it's current state is quite enjoyable and I look forward to further levels and conent.  Currently there is one mode available entitled Disc" with three levels accessible.  You play an unknown program fleeing the system.  This is a runner style game where you follow a prearranged set path with your movement limited to:  left/right
recommended:
jump and are unable to speed up or slow down.

A number of powerups are available at the start of each level that you can purchase using energy bytes that you earn in game.  This allows you to customize your character with various power-ups and companions that can affect how you play a level.

The visuals in the game are remarkable and harken back to the look of Tron 2.0 (a great fps if you haven't played) combined with the character designs from the newer Tron Evolution game.  It is also amusing to see the devs giving nods to the source material when you rack up an "MCP Combo" or "Space Paranoid" combo to name a few.

All in all a fun little game that challenges you to keep playing in order to beat your previous scores and earn the 3 Light Bytes (aka gold stars) per level.

The store page lists partial controller support.  I was able to play the game with no problem using an Xbox One controller.  In fact the in-game control options showed such a controller so that may be an indication that the devs plan to bring it to the Xbox One some time in the future."

reviewText:
Pros
- The fact that a Tron game came out in 2016 is unbelievable.
- Unreal 4 engine looks good and the visual style of the movie is preserved, although altered in a number of ways.
- Game is fun and plays really well.
- Playing as characters from the movie and show is a nice edition, although it doesn't feature Sam from Legacy for whatever reason, or old Kevin for that matter.

Cons
- There's really not much here. It has a sub-iPhone level of content, minimalist gameplay, and is probably just high of what could run on an iPhone as well. I have a suspicion that this was originally developed for mobile and adapted for PC when they discovered that it would be just a bit too much for mobile to run.
- Unreal 4's bad parts show as strongly as its good parts: textures will take their sweet time loading, in particular.
- No graphics options. The game could really use them.
- Random frame drops. I'm talking about baaaaaaad frame drops. Game ending frame drops. And they always happen in the same place.
- Permeated by micro transactions. You can play without, just with only the default loadout.
- Really easy. Insultingly easy, even.
- They couldn't license the movie soundtrack. Enough said.

My entire experience playing this game was me staring at the screen not believing that anything from the Tron IP was released in 2016. But it's a far cry from what I really want in my life: which is, of course, another movie. Still worth it on sale for a Tron fan.

reviewText:
First off let's be clear: this is a runner ~ obviously that's in the title but make no mistake, there is nothing else here but running (either on foot or cycle). I've seen some negative reviews of people who get the game expecting more. There's no story, there's no other modes.

Having said that, it is a decent running game. It's graphics and sounds are superior to most running games (which are often just phone app ports). And overall it captures the Tron asthetics well. The difficulty is on the higher side for running games which gives it some replayability as you master the dozens of levels.

The biggest con is the game is setup with a cash shop. You can get bits just from playing but the game will try to sell you bits for real money. Honestly I would suggest getting the Deluxe Edition; not only do you get all the DLC levels with it but you get 11,000 bits. (the deluxe is cheaper than buying the game + DLC and then the 11,000 bits on top of that is essentially free). With 11,000 bits + what you can earn in game you will be able to avoid the cash shop entirely.

I picked the deluxe edition up on sale for under $20 and I feel like the game is worth around that. Not sure I would pay for it when it's not on sale.
